content:
She had the most beautiful smile in the world.

I was the luckiest man on the planet for 8 months and 2 days. 
Her smile could unite nations, and her hug was warmer than the sun. 
Yesterday she was hit by a car and passed away, together with our soon-to-be-born daughter. 
If only we had more time. 

We met on August 24, 2021. 
It was a weird event, some form of a 60-minute panel discussion. 
I have spent 59 of those - staring at a girl in the back row. THE girl.

We met again, I insisted. With every sentence she said, I fell deeper and deeper in love. She was a visionary, building her dreams into the future! A strong little girl, bootstrapping a fantastic tech company. She would organize international collaboration and never ask for credit. She would always find time to build schools in post-war regions at the cost of sleep and well being. She would put bars so high that nothing and no one would match her criteria. That's how the world saw her, but to me, she was my sweet little pumpkin. The softest person I knew. 

I was 26, and she was 28. We lived in pain and loneliness until we found each other. It was a match made in heavens. The first girl I ever kissed. We haven't had a single fight. Citizens of different countries with entirely different life journeys, we couldn't be more similar. It was absolute harmony and true happiness. She changed me entirely.

Sona. My Sona. 

Sona 🌿 Mnatsakanyan

My LinkedIn one line intro goes by “I sold gum at Wrigleys, Ads at Google (@Google), Samosas at TBK (@thebohrikitchen) and Burgers at McDonalds (@Mcdonalds). When I'm not selling anything, I like to Sail.” ⛵

Years ago, probably in my first year at Google, I remember ogling at folks Sailing, while I stood bent over on the edge of Gateway of India or from an Alibaug Ferry I assumed that I was staring at the Tatas and Ambanis of Mumbai.

Manifestation is a real thing. A few months later a friend asked me to join him for a Sailing Class, where I learnt about the Colaba Sailing Club. A no-nonsense club built for aspiring sailors (leisure or otherwise).
The benefit the club offers is access to some gorgeous Seabird & Lightning class boats, access to the sailing community and ultimately the superpower to start sailing without any prior expertise whatsoever.

Over the next few weeks, I’m going to start sharing content from my Sails with the objective of
(1) to hopefully entertain you
(2) to evangelise this gorgeous hobby/sport
(3) and encourage you to join the CSC in time for the post-monsoon Season!


As the Danish author, Isak Dinesen said “The cure for anything is saltwater – sweat, tears, or the sea.” 🌊

(In the short video, I’ve taken one of the CSC boats out for a fairly rough afternoon Sail. This is on a weekend in April. Every year after Holi, the wind shifts and starts to come from the South/ Prongs Lighthouse. I wonder if these are the onset of the SW Monsoon Winds?)

Does your CI/CD build take a lot of time? 

I was working on a project and saw it was taking over 30mins to complete the build. So I did some research on how to reduce it. 

Here are some of the methods to reduce the pipeline time 👇

1. Write optimized UTs
Writing UTs are easy and knowing what to write and how to write is important.

2. Use mockups in tests
You don't need to test your database or API connections in every UTs, replace API calls or DB calls with mocks.

3. Delete old codes
Actively delete the codes/tests no longer in use, the CI server won't waste its precious time on those tests.

4. Pararellize your build
There are many ways you can run your maven/npm build in parallel (talking about 1 build running on multiple threads)

5. Move to micro-services architecture
One of the pros of micro-services over monoliths is lesser build time.

6. Cache your dependencies
Most of the CI servers already cache it but do check

I will be posting a video on how to write optimised UTs on my Youtube(in comments) tomorrow, do check it out.

The number of phishing frauds has gone through the roof, and everybody is being targeted. The only way to protect yourself is to not trust anybody asking for money or offering something that seems too good to be true. Here are a few types of frauds I have come across recently. 

Impersonating Govt officials and other higher authorities and asking for charitable donations or money for other things. Many folks on our team have received social media and WhatsApp messages saying I was in some urgent need of money from fake accounts. 

Fake Instagram profiles of well-known people are created by copying everything from the original profile. The followers of these fake accounts then get messages to buy paid courses, scammy penny stocks and crypto.
 Here's an example of my ID being used. (image)

Luring customers to share login credentials by using greed. Once the fraudster has access to the account, losses are created and money is transferred to other trading accounts by trading penny stocks, illiquid options or transferring stocks. (link in comments)

The craziest one is fraudsters advertising the customer support number of a large company on Google. When the customer calls up the number, the scamsters ask for a UPI transfer or send UPI pull requests from handles that seem like they belong to the main brand.

content:
Philip Kotler once said, ‘Good companies meet market needs; great companies create markets.’
This push that a company needs to evolve from one of the good ones to a great one is Brand Management.

Marketers are no strangers to the concept of Brand Management, yet many choose to ignore it. People often forget that it is no longer enough to satisfy your customers; we need to delight them. Brand management is personifying a company! Keeping this variance of marketers in mind, Symbiosis Institute of Digital & Telecom Management (SIDTM), Pune has introduced ‘Brand Management’ as a subject under the ‘Marketing and Finance’ specialization.

Students choosing to study Brand Management will be exposed to various branding strategies, project budgeting, launches alongside Integrated Media Communications, and the theory of consumer data analytics in the marketing domain.

SYMBIOSIS INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY
Symbiosis Centre for Alumni Engagement

For any data-driven approach for physical simulations for high dimensional parameter space, sampling becomes a big issue. To mitigate this issue, we have developed parametric physics-informed greedy latent space dynamics identification algorithms, so called gLaSDI. This is an extension of our previous paper, LaSDI, so gLaSDI follows the same framework as LaSDI, i.e., compress the simulation data with auto-encoder to form a latent space and identify dynamics in the latent space with a predefined ODE. Unlike LaSDI, gLaSDI relies on physics-informed error indicator to determine where in parameter space to sample on the fly during the training phase, which leads to sub-optimal (if not optimal) sampling procedure. 

For example, the figure below compares the accuracy of LaSDI with uniform grid sampling and physics-informed greedy sampling. Although both approaches use the same number of training data, i.e., 36, gLaSDI achieves the maximum relative error around 4%, while LaSDI with the uniform sampling suffers with the maximum relative error close to  250%. 

You can find all about gLaSDI at the following arXiv paper:

https://lnkd.in/gDmXu65j

#Kudos to Xiaolong He, William (Bill) Fries, Jon Belof, Jiun-Shyan Chen for this awesome work!

I am sure you will enjoy this work, so please do take advantage of it!

A data catalog is a collection of metadata, combined with data management and search tools, that helps analysts and other data users to find the data that they need, serves as an inventory of available data, and provides information to evaluate fitness data for intended uses. By providing analysts with a single, comprehensive view of their customers, a data catalog can help uncover new opportunities for cross-selling, up-selling and targeted promotions. A data catalog differs from a data dictionary in its ability to search and retrieve information. The Data Catalog Market was valued at $523.55 million in 2020, and is expected to reach $1,788.49 million by 2026, registering a CAGR of approximately 23.1% over the forecast period (2021 - 2026).

In this week’s Know Your Data {KYD}, we present you with a brief overview of data catalog.

How To Find All Regions An #AWS Service Is Available.

Writing management tools have always been fun and a challenge. Fun because it’s challenging. You always learn a thing or two. For example, we learned yet one more weird fact about AWS API inconsistency, maybe you already know- The S3 Bucket location API always returns null for all the buckets in US East (N. Virginia) region and returns actual AWS API region names for all other locations. Not an interesting bit of information unless you’re dealing with AWS cloud at the API level.

AWS continuously rolls out new innovative AWS services and enhancements to the existing services. Keeping track of AWS services, and the AWS resources created is of tremendous importance for security, cost and general cloud hygiene. Hence we started CloudYali to be the single only source of truth, which has all the AWS resource (AWS assets) information for all AWS services being deployed from all the AWS regions. Missing even a single resource from any remote region or AWS service is simply out of question. This is easier said than done, but that’s where the challenge comes.

Hello Connections,
2-3 days back, I participated in a weekly challenge by Crowwwn. And it was a real thrill and fun for me to participate in it. Since it was my first challenge, I faced some problems, but Suvam Prasad helped me out, and I'm thankful to him. 
The problem statement was like this:
When I use dating apps, I want to verify the other person is genuine and let my friends and family know who I will be out with, so I can go out safely.

I came up with some solutions, which were as follows-
1) The option of scanning where the user has to scan their face will automatically be verified with the pictures they've uploaded previously. From this, we can ensure the person's identity is real or not.
2) Or there is a second option where it requires the user to upload their KYC document (any 1) to proceed.
The user has the option to choose between the first and second one.
3) I also added some safety tips for dating to keep the user informed.
4) I added a GPS option through which location can be shared with friends and family to keep track if the person decides to go on a date.
I am still iterating on it. Your feedback would be valuable in helping me iterate and bring out a better version of it.

So this was my UX as well as UI Presentation.
 Thank You! Crowwwn for giving me this opportunity. I hope you like it, and any feedback is much appreciated!
Thanks & Regards

Few tips for students, generally for staying a balanced and contented career/Life: 
1) Never compare yourself with others, you are unique. Everything is subjective: successful career, papers, partners, girl/boy friends, materialistic possession etc. 
2) Be ambitious: set small achievable-realistic goals, and a long term goal where you want to be ultimately.
3) Read a lot and don't hesitate to discuss or reach out to people if you need clarification/guidance/motivation.
4) Increase your network, but don't bombard other's inbox with insensitive queries, comments, etc.
5) Organise and be disciplined in your approaches.
6) There is no substitute to Hard work, but in today's world it's also important to Work hard Smartly. Don't hesitate to learn/adapt new technology, approaches and interpretations. 
7) Encourage criticism with positive attitude. There is always a possibility that someone would come up with better ways to resolve a problem.
8) Inculcate a good hobby. Personally, I have benefited a lot being away from lab trekking during the weekends. It's relaxing and many a times, best experimental plans came while trekking. 
9) Be approachable, and have a cordial relationship with your colleagues, friends, and spouse.
10) Slightest moment when you feel that you need help, please don't hesitate to reach out to your friends, family and take professional counselling.  #students #career

Recently a guy reached to me on LinkedIn with a concern that he was not getting interview calls. This is how the conversation went-

ajay: hey Prankur, I have been trying into so many different companies but my resume is not getting shortlist. Can I share my resume with you for the review?

me: sure, let me see. 

After few minutes....

Your resume seems fine to me, there should be any problem in getting an interview call.

ajay: Can you refer me at Amazon?

me: Sure, Please share the relevant job id's matching your skill set along with your resume.

ajay: sure, here it is.

me: You will receive an email, once I referred. If you don't receive any such mail within one week, just ping me here again.

ajay: sure, thanks again.

After 7 days

ajay: prankur, I haven't not received any referral mail till now. did you get a chance to refer me?

me: yes, I referred you the very next day. Referral mail generally takes 3 days. You must have received it till now. Please check your spam folder.

ajay: I checked all other folders, but couldn't find any mail of referral.

me: 1 sec, does the email mentioned in your resume is correct?

ajay: yes, it should be correct. let me check once again. ohh!!, there is one character missing in the email mentioned in my resume.

me: I hope you got the reason why you are not getting interview calls from companies. Send me your correct email address, I will refer you.

ajay: Thanks Prankur, I will make sure that it won't happen again.

-----------_----------_--------------

 While referring candidates, I have seen so many candidates mentioning undeliverable email addresses in their resume. It can cost you an opportunity. Do check you email address and contact details before submitting your application.

There's always gonna be someone earning better than you, someone more successful than you, someone more intelligent than you in your life and workplace.

But, what matters is are you content with what you're doing!! Do not put yourself down seeing others. Take it as a healthy competition but not a toxic comparision. Be grateful for today, but hopeful for tomorrow.

:)

My launch station !
 
Diphu railway station - Wikipedia has just 5 lines assigned to this place. But for me this railway station will always be so much more than just another station. It will always be a place that I have used to tick off milestones....a lot of them.
 
This is …
 
- The place where I took my first ever train ride with my dad, 2 decades back to reach to the city for my higher studies. 
 
- The place where I first experienced the anxiety of stepping into an unknown world that I was going to explore and still got excited with my hopes for a better future and gigantic big dreams.
 
- The place that convinced me what I had here was nice but not enough ... not at-least for me. As the first generation to go to college from my family, this place was my gateway to go out and explore the world.
 
- The place that I consciously lied about to my Delhi University friends ( I would say…Rajdhani doesn’t stop in Diphu.. it’s too small a place and hence I don’t travel via Rajdhani . While in reality, 20 years back - Rajdhani tickets were priced 4x more than the regular train ticket in the North East express. I simply couldn’t afford a ticket in the Rajdhani). It’s strange how an adolescent mind, albeit still learning is more concerned of optics.
 
- When I started earning..…That very lie encouraged me to write 3 letters to the Indian Railways asking them to add Diphu as a stop so that I could finally experience a Rajdhani ride to my home town. I don’t think any of my letters ever reached anyone significant within the railways then, but I was glad when I found out that Rajdhani stops for 1 min in there now.
 
The irony is - I have never till date travelled by a Rajdhani. Once I had the means … I didn’t have the luxury of time . Somehow while chasing bigger dreams … travelling by the Rajdhani went lower and lower in my to do list.
 
Going back home is very special for everyone. This one was even more so. Because my kid tagged along and is grown enough to ask questions (a lot of them!) and seek answers. As a parent I may be able to give in to most of the rationale demands of my son now but I have realised that I can never give him the experience of my struggle.  
 
But I will try to give him a lot of exposure to acknowledge and appreciate the roots that his mom comes from and is immensely proud of. And I will hope someday he finds his own source of inspirations. 
 
To all small town girls and (yes boys) moving to the big city with bigger dreams.…..I know your struggle is real but believe me the reality of that dream is even more fulfilling. 
 
So Dream on …..

#future #learning #travel #startup #newexperiences #dreamstoreality #smalltown #india

Yesterday while returning home, I saw this extra large banner/ outdoor ad of iPhone 13 Pro. The glaring powdered green phone in the banner proudly presents itself in "Alpine Green" color. I was wondering on why the hell an European mountain range gets the name of a color (proudly being sold in India) and not a mountain from India! The Green could have easily been the Nilgiris Green or Himalayan Green! So, what went wrong that our landmark landscapes, buildings, heritage never gets the name of a color but the western ones? 

Well, the issue remains with us. We never emphasised upon this idea of Indianizing the colors and it's names. No Indian brands ever gave a color name as Nilgiris Green, Himalayan Blue or Agra Fort Red! We feel that the color names that resonates with exotic locations/ landmarks/ heritage are more precious than our own. 

Hence, the change of mindset has to be within us first prior to seeking the same appearing in international brands. We should be proud of our colors, culture and customs. 

I dream, one day the International brands like iPhone will launch their products with names such as 'Thar Yellow', 'Nilgiris Green', 'Himalayan Blue'. 

#Indiamatters #Colormatters #india

An Emotional goodbye to Bangalore
9th April 2022
 
When I stepped out of the airport door to board the IndiGo (InterGlobe Aviation Ltd)  bus till flight, I had tears rolling down my eyes, I looked around at the Bangalore airport as if it's the last time I am here. Though I know I'll be keep coming and going to Bangalore for some or the other thing. But that moment was an emotional one. 

Bangalore has taught me the way of life, to live on my own. I started my career in Bangalore and here I have made really good friends like family who are closest to my heart. Venkatesh Venugopal  Pramod puthoor ADARSH G Kruti Kukadolkar Madhuri Krishna Murthy Nupur Solanki  Jayati Joshi  It would be a long list if I start to jot down all of them. 

I have had good 5 years ( -2 on and off due to covid) in Bangalore, both professionally and personally. 

Here I am carrying same professional career with me Bosch Global Software Technologies at Pune, with same team virtually.

Shoppers don’t just want snacks delivered ASAP. They need shampoo and deodorant in a pinch, too.

Enter: instant-delivery companies.

You run out of shampoo or lotion or something, it’s not something you typically plan for. The ability to have these things delivered relatively quickly, it sort of sets up nicely for a lot of beauty products.

Gorillas, which already works with brands like Dove, Olay, and Aveeno, sees plenty more potential in the space.

So do other startups. Gopuff partnered with Coty in 2020 to drop off beauty fixes in 30 minutes. FastAF Technologies, Inc. now works with premium brands to get their goods to consumers - in New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco, for now - in under two hours. About a third (36%) of FastAF’s order composition is beauty.

Value proposition for some of these rapid-delivery companies is in driving up basket sizes and, by extension, driving up margins.

Ultimately, however, beauty is a growing category for rapid delivery, which is why both FastAF and Gorillas are sticking to diversifying their product mix.

Do you order beauty products from quick commerce firms?

Simran: "I know HTML. I know CSS. I know JS.
But I can't write code. 😞
I don't know where to start. 😩 "

Me: Every new web developer goes through this phase Simran.

Simran: What's the solution?
Me: `Apply theory to practice` ✅

S: How to practice?
M: Make projects 🕺🏻

S: What projects?
M: As a beginner take baby steps, start slow with a basic project. 😇

S: What basic project?
M: Why not build your own portfolio website. 😌

S: How to build a portfolio website?
Me: Here you go 👇
0. Start from scratch, build a static site
1. Write HTML & CSS to make it beautiful
2. Use JS + creativity and play with code
3. & don't just leave it to localhost:5500
4. Host it at `www.SimranIsAwesome .com` 😉

This will help you apply the basics of HTML, CSS, JS.
And as you make more projects keep adding them to your portfolio here. 😇

After you finish it,
move onto a little advanced project which involves talking to APIs and a little more cool stuff.

So what are you waiting for Simran?
Hurry up, get started! 🔥

<after 10 minutes>
S: Yayayayay, I've bought the domain 🤩
Me: Wow, you're fast. 🚀

<after 2 minutes>
Me: But I see `SimranIsAwesome .com` still available for purchase, that's weird! 🤯

S: Yeah, because I've got `SimranIsBeyondAwesome .com` 😎

“I caught my first glimpse of the island from the scratched window of a 6-seater plane built in the 1970s – the only way to cover the 700 odd kilometres from mainland Chile. We took off from a navy strip in Santiago’s wilderness and flew low over the Pacific Ocean. I felt my heart pounding amid the turbulence and skipping a beat as we descended past the desolate, volcanic mountains into a landing strip plucked out of the moon. At the boat jetty next to the airport, we were greeted by troupes of sea lions frolicking in the Pacific waters – a befitting introduction to an island believed to host more biodiversity than the famous Galapagos.

Volcanic rock formations, Mars-like red soil deserts, forests hundreds of years old that evolved in isolation, the endangered red fire-crown hummingbird - over the past few weeks, we’ve been incredibly lucky to hike, camp, kayak, snorkel and experience some of Isla Robinson Crusoe’s wild beauty. With nothing but the Pacific Ocean on all sides for hundreds of kilometres, this feels like the furthest place on earth. But it’s also starting to feel a little like home…,” says Shivya Nath, an eco-conscious storyteller and traveller, a few weeks after landing on the remote island of Robinson Crusoe, situated 700 km off mainland Chile in a tiny archipelago called Juan Fernandez Islands.

Empowered by Lenovo’s smart technology, Shivya spent a month with other volunteers selected by Lenovo for its Work for Humankind program initiated in collaboration with NGO Island Conservation and the Chilean government. They have been working remotely from Robinson Crusoe Island while dedicating 20 hours a week to volunteer in conservation activities and initiatives to empower the island community.

To know more - https://bit.ly/3MoiI0S

In Partnership with Lenovo India
#RobinsonCrusoe #WFH #WorkForHumankind

We usually choose any one of the above services to travel in Bangalore. Currently my wife is carrying. We always ask the driver to slowly drive in up and downs. Dear automobile service providers if you put a simple checkmark in your mobile apps which passengers can select, that indicates to the driver that there is a pregnant woman travelling in the current trip, It would be a great help to all the pregnant womens.

This seems a simple feature but it may saves a life.

Minimum downtime & optimum utilisation is at the heart of the sustainable success of any technological resources. This statement stands true as far as compression for short videos is concerned.

While compression aids in delivering videos in ready-made formats, it also should be packed with crucial parameters that provide better control and at the same time make the entire process fast & efficient.

In this blog, we talk about the CLI tool that we have created enabling optimisation with a renewed focus on user-friendliness. Adhering to strict standards on quality ensures greater output during playback. Through this processing mechanism, we have achieved a method for easy compression while drastically reducing the cost involved.

Capgemini and Everest Group have published a joint thought leadership paper titled "Payment System Modernization for Innovation at Speed and Scale."
 
This report lays out the payments innovation agenda along with the challenges and best practices for payments IT modernization and covers the following topics:
Key market drivers of payments IT modernization
Payments innovation opportunities and perspectives for mid-sized banks to build the business case
Risks and benefits of two alternate approaches i.e., Big-bang and progressive
Challenges and best practices for banks to consider on their modernization journey
 
With legacy systems, multiple layers of capabilities built on top of them, and a limited budget to upgrade, small and mid-sized banks have largely not shifted to modern payment systems and are struggling to compete. As these small and mid-sized banks explore the incremental modernization approach, they are looking forward to revamping their front office systems to improve stakeholder experiences, explore off-the-shelf payment technologies and analyze cloud readiness with technology service providers. #payments #Capgemini #everestgroup

Ratan Tata is an inspiration for everyone and doesn’t require any introduction. 

1937: He was born on 28 December 1937 where he had a challenging childhood. 

1977: Ratan Tata was forced to shut down a revolutionary unit project because the core management did not sanction funds for the project.

1991: Faced criticism when he was declared as the successor of Tata Group by JRD Tata. 

1998: He decided to enter the car industry and launched its first car model titled Tata indica. 

But it was disliked by the public and was a huge failure. 

1999: Due to the company's failure he decided to sell Tata motors to Ford. 

However, Ford managed to insult Ratan Tata. 

As Ratan Tata famously has said: “Take the stones people throw at you. And use them to build a monument.” 

With these words Ratan Tata returned to Mumbai without signing the deal. 

Later, newer upgrades of the car, named Indica V2, quickly became a mass favourite.

A man with a simple lifestyle and golden heart saw several failures and converted them into success.

2008: Tata saved the Ford company from getting bankrupt by purchasing its two luxurious brands Jaguar and Land Rover. 

66% of Tata Sons' equity is held by the Tata Trusts, and dividends flow directly to support the philanthropic work of the Trusts.

He is the reason why Tata Group became a global powerhouse within the span of 3 decades.

Ratan Tata is a true global leadership inspiration who has lifted thousands of young talents and showcased India to the world.

My friend is from a rich family but his grades were not good enough to get him into a University in Singapore. So instead of enrolling into a University in the US or UK, he took a job as a salesman in Dunlop Singapore, initially selling t-shirts, rackets and golf balls too! 

The lack of tertiary education did not hold him back because academic knowledge does not cultivate an appetite for initiative, risk-taking and seizing opportunities. That was learned from countless hours of interning (he called it free child labor)  in his father's business. 

Today he is a multi-millionaire because of his apartment leasing/airB&B business and property investments.

At 62, he continues running the business with gusto.

When an employee is sick, he would take over and clean the apartment, do repairs, clear the drains; clean the toilets, pick up customers from the airport, drive them to the apartment, check them in, make recommendations about which local sights to visit, and how to get there.

Being from a rich family help a lot but his humility, intelligence and work ethic are what made the difference.

I am thrilled to announce that I am stepping into the next phase of my career and joining a brand new team at RealPage, Inc.

When I pivoted my career from the private sector to the Government of India, I faced a major cultural shock. 

In the private sector, I called my juniors, peers, and my bosses- all by their first name. 

I entered the world of government and everyone addressed officers as "Sir/Ma'am". 

It's not that I didn't respect my bosses or superiors in government, but suddenly calling someone "Sir/Ma'am" seemed hierarchical, and frankly colonial too.

What bewildered me was that even freshly minted young professionals who had cleared IAS exam were the new "Sir/Ma'am". 

As small as the connotation may seem, subtle hierarchy in the name of salutations trains people to be submissive and junior not in terms of rank but in thoughts, #innovation, and ideas. And that erodes system's #growth.

Now, I am not against IAS officers. I am all in for their extraordinary contribution to the nation and perhaps they are not to be blamed for settling into this age-old culture. 

But if they won't change the culture of "Ma'am/Sir", who will ?

Our system needs change. And that change can come while learning to be respectful but not submissive. We need to question and change the school principal like treatment of government officers. 

Today, as a Co-CEO, I politely request anyone who calls me Ma'am to address me by my first name because I know this "Sir/Maam" Wall will set back my organization by decades.

We need a more liberal working culture if we want our economy and society to prosper. 

If 21st-century Indian won't, who will?

Making a difference was defined by people who created value before claiming any value 🍕 

Having had the priviledge of education and workex from some of the top places in the world, it almost felt like a responsibility to give back. 

We both started-up full time. He started up in #healthcare and I in #k12education - to solve some of the biggest problems that have bothered us for years. 

Result —> we are now a home with two founders 😄

Imagine the chaos, firefighting, stress, and the number of sleepless nights 😩 

But also, imagine the volume of intellectual debates, moments of happiness, and the deep gratification 🥰

Language constructs our perception of reality.

As a non-binary person, I do feel excluded when someone starts a meeting by saying "Welcome ladies and gentlemen" or something to that effect. I'd rather have my gender identity included in the greeting as well, it's nice to be welcomed, if others next to me are too. Hearing that kind of language, used still quite regularly, does not boost my hope of seeing a future that is free from the gender binary norm.

We at Accenture receive regularly training in the topics of inclusion and diversity, which I really love. I recall seeing some of these words in some of those trainings as well, and thinking I should really, really remember to stop using the term "guys" or Finnish equivalents and replace it with "folks". Being non-binary myself I probably do remember a bit more often than an average binary person to not make assumptions about someone's gender indentity based on their physical looks and first name, but honestly, certain type of language is so ingrained in my vocabulary as well due to 40+ years of exposure to that type of language, that despite good intentions, I often catch myself slipping as well. Unlearning of habits you've carried most of your life may be slow but I'm positive we can all get there if we give it the good old college try. 

Small effort for everyone, enormous significance to folks who are so used to have their existence not validated same way others' are in normal everyday life that they don't even bother to put up a fight in fear of being seen as a nitpicking fusspot.
 #inclusion #diversity #inclusivelanguage

When you call the electrician about an electrical problem do you ask, “Why should I hire you?”

You don’t, because they would say, “I’m busy. Is there anything else you need?” 

They are not here to impress you. 

If you didn’t have a problem, you wouldn’t have called them.

No one expects to be able to talk down to an electrician (or plumber, carpenter, etc.).

It’s only in the arena of employment that we teach kids [and adults] that they have to prove themselves to new people over and over, all the time, forever…

 …or that is normal & appropriate to jump through hoops to win the chance to do the kind of work you’ve been doing for years.

It’s a sickness, but we won’t climb out of it until we see it and see the degree to which the pervasive, toxic mindset toward employment – “roll over and play the submissive dog on the job interview, and also on the job” - affects our own thinking.

It’s not bad to realize that you’ve been brainwashed. 

It’s freeing.

It’s empowering! 

You learned a lot of BS as a kid the same way we all did. 

Now you see it. 

Now you can step out of it, and into your power.

I am beyond excited to announce that I will be joining Google at the end of May! 🔵🔴🟡🟢

I will share more details when I can, but in short: it is a senior research role at  the intersection of UX, engineering and developer productivity. I will get to work with Elizabeth Churchill and a lot of other brilliant folks on new technologies and tools that will empower developers to build better products and solutions. While the teams are mainly in California and New York, I will be working remotely from Aalborg - doing the long commute when needed ✈️

Having worked with a broad spectrum of Google technologies for more than a decade and applied these through teaching, research, consulting and startup projects, it is an amazing opportunity to get to work 'at the core' on some of the foundational technologies and new products that will power future innovation and potentially reach billions of people. It is also a dream role, as it affords me the opportunity to stay in touch with the academic, startup and developer communities. I look forward to contributing to these from 'the other side' going forward 🌎 

While starting a new adventure is amazing, it is also very hard to say goodbye to the wonderful colleagues, students and friends at AU Engineering, Aarhus University. Having started and built ORBIT Lab from its basic ideas up to the growing and thriving tech and innovation hub it has become, I am very proud to have been part of this journey and amazing team. Together we have accomplished so much over the past years - yet there are still so much more to be done.
The potential and stakes are high, as the department has an exemplary ability to create the talent, knowledge and solutions needed for many of the big societal challenges the world is facing, and a unique engineering and research DNA that fosters innovation and collaboration.
For all of our collaborators and community members: rest assured that everything is in the best of hands. I am confident that the department, along with ORBIT Lab and all of the innovation initiatives, collaborations and projects across Aarhus University and beyond, will continue and grow - and I will enjoy following your continued successes and impact! 🚀

Big life altering decisions are both difficult and exciting and I feel very grateful to have made it this far and been offered this new opportunity. I want to give some heartfelt thanks to Bela Kriger, M.C. Altman, and Michael Davis, who caringly and expertly led me through the recruitment process, and to my interviewers for interesting and challenging discussions while also taking time to answer questions and share personal insights about work and culture. My thanks extend to the Googler contacts, friends and family who gave advice and encouragement all the way - you know who you are ❤️
 
I look forward to humbly putting on my noogler hat and starting out on this new adventure!!

#google #noogler #technology #ux #research #engineering #innovation #devtools #adventure
